ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK AND SITUATION OF THE PUBLIC ENTERPRISE SECTOR 1. Introduction. A study of the parastatal sector conducted in June 1996 in cooperation with the General Directorate of Economic Affairs and the Privatization Authority (Commissariat general a la privatisation) identified the financial difficulties of state-owned enterprises in Gabon and the burden they place on government finance. This study confirmed the earlier results of a survey of the private sector and specific sectoral studies. These studies have been particularly useful in devising strategies based on opening the sectors concerned to competition and on developing plans to privatize public enterprises. 2. Following the financial crisis caused by the 1986 collapse of oil prices, Gabon embarked on a policy to clean up its parastatal sector. Its objectives were to reduce the sector's pressure--in the form of subsidies and the cost of government consumption--on government finance, and to make the economy more competitive. A series of studies on the enterprises was conducted as part of the Structural Adjustment Program concluded with the World Bank, but the adjustment measures adopted were partially jeopardized by the social unrest that occurred in the early 1990s. 3. Starting in 1992, and even more so after the devaluation of the CFA franc, the Government decided to recenter its role on its primary functions, a choice entailing a move to divest itself of directly productive enterprises backed by a Development Strategy Statement and an accompanying World Bank economic recovery loan. This new approach was initiated under the adjustment program supported by the IMF's ESAF (1995-98), which includes an ambitious program to restructure and privatize the parastatal sector. The project presented in this document is in support of that program. 4. Structure and Role of the Parastatal Sector in the Economy. The parastatal sector comprises some forty enterprises doing business in all sectors of the economy. These enterprises, listed in Annex I, are public establishments of an industrial and a commercial nature, state-owned corporations, semi-public companies, or companies in which the Government is a shareholder. Most of these enterprises have monopolies in the sector in which they operate, whether it be telecommunications, water and electricity, or the import and export of agricultural and forest products. 5. The parastatal sector's contribution to national production accounts for 7.5% of GDP. It employs 18,000 workers, or 20% of the formal sector work force, and its share

Negative returns were seen primarily among enterprises in the water and electricity, transportation and agribusiness sectors. Because of their weight in the economy and the new opportunities created by the change in the exchange rate and the introduction of the UDEAC's tax and customs reforms, a number of these enterprises' has been identified by the Government as priority candidates for reform of the sector. Moreover, an analysis has revealed that the negative results declared by these enterprises are largely artificial, and are not related to their cash flow. Constraints on the Parastatal Sector and the Projected Policy. The problems encountered by the parastatal sector present a serious obstacle to the sustainable development of the Gabonese economy. Public enterprises greatly underuse their production capacity, which generally ranges from 40 to 65%. This underuse is mainly attributed to the following factors: (a) organizational constraints, such as quality of management, technological choices, the organization of production, and the shortage of capital for investment; and (b) a lack of competitiveness, along with rigid markets and an inflexible business environment. 9. To cope with this situation, the Gabonese authorities have decided to lighten the heavy financial, economic, and social burden placed on the country by the public enterprise sector, and to promote the development of a local private sector and private foreign investment. To do this, the Government has adopted the program described below, which focuses on setting up a legal and regulatory system that favors private investment. This program is based on the following: (a) opening up the economy; and (b) privatizing the major sectoral government enterprises and selling the Government minority shareholdings. 3
 10. Implementation of the privatization program is based on a well-established strategic choice. In the initial stage, the authorities intend to sell only their minority shareholdings in a certain number of private companies and their majority shares in seven major enterprises, each in a different sector. These include SEEG (electricity and water), OPT/TIG (telecommunications, and the postal and financial services), OCTRA (railways), AIRGABON (air transport), AGROGABON (palm oil), HEVEGAB (rubber), and CIMENTGAB (cement production). This decision is based on lessons learned from privatization programs conducted in Africa and other parts of the world, including the following considerations: (a) the limits imposed by the administrative, technical, social, and political capacity, but also the limited capacity of the market for privatization; and (b) the need to have a successful, positive experience, and to ensure social and political support for the process. 11. Moreover, under a law passed in 1983, all companies setting up business in Gabon must pay the Government 10 percent of their capital. This law, which was suspended in 1989, also applied to the capital increases of these firms. A total of around 200 companies were affected by this law. About 150 of these firms are still operating, but it is estimated that only 50 of them are of any significance in terms of the volume of their business and the size of their profits. The Gabonese Government is also proposing to sell the shares it acquired under a 1992 law beneficial to Gabonese investors, and especially to small holders and institutional investors. 12. Constraints to Developing the Private Sector and the Anticipated Policies. The private sector is expected to play a decisive role in Gabon's prosperity and increased standard of living. It is clear that the program to open up the economy and privatize will spark new opportunities for the growth and development of the private sector. Many reforms are still needed, however, to improve the business environment and to build the country's institutional capacity. Creation of an environment favorable to private enterprise will in fact facilitate the privatization program and encourage private investment. To accomplish this, the Government has undertaken a broad program of institutional, legal, regulatory, fiscal, and financial reforms designed to overhaul the environment in which the private sector operates. The main thrust of this program, whose components are part of the adjustment program with the IMF, is based on the concepts of facilitation, transparency, and equity. An Investment Charter, in the process of being finalized, embodies the commitments and reforms being put in place. This Charter was the subject of intensive consultations with local operators and the Bretton Woods institutions. 13. Gabonese businessmen view the high level of taxes and the tax administration as the most serious threats to business and growth. Problems related to the exchange rate are ranked in third place. This, however, may reflect the instability following the 1994 CFA franc devaluation. The fourth- and fifth-ranking problems are considered to be the high cost of financing and the difficulty in gaining access to this financing, in that order. 4
 14. To eliminate these problems, the Government will pursue efforts to revise and harmonize the system of incentives, while stepping up the pace of fiscal and customs reforms agreed in the context of the UDEAC. 15. Benefits of the Project. The reforms advocated under this project are vital to economic stabilization and renewed growth in several ways. From an economic standpoint, they should produce the following results: (a) considerable reduction in real terms of the average cost of production factors such as water and electricity ( 18%) and telecommunications (35%); (b) improvement in the quality of services provided and greater access to those services by the people; (c) improvement in the productivity of labor, while maintaining employment levels, by developing the private sector; and (d) substantial decrease in--or even the elimination of--subsidies to enterprises. 16. The communications component, restructuring of social security, and the possibility for small Gabonese investors to participate in the privatization process should enhance the people's understanding and awareness of the country's need for these reforms, and should therefore trigger their active participation in implementation of the program, which is essential if the program of economic reforms is to succeed. 17. Quantification of Project Costs and Benefits. The total financial costs of the project are estimated at CFAF 9 billion, or US$16 million. They can be broken down as follows: * Building popular support for privatization: CFAF 567 million, or US$1 million; * Establishing a regulatory system to govern competition and building the Government's regulatory capacity: CFAF 1.7 billion, or US$3 million; * Restructuring and privatizing the major public enterprises: CFAF 3.7 billion, or US$6.5 million; * Increasing the participation of nationals in privatization of the parastatal sector: CFAF 567 million, or US$1 million; * Modernizing the legal and regulatory environment in which business operates: CFAF 850 million, or US$1.5 million; * Ensuring adequate management of the program and project: CFAF 1.7 billion, or US$3 million. 18. A dynamic cost-benefit analysis of the project shows the following financing needs during the first four years, from 1997 to 2000: the total cumulative amount of net costs should not surpass CFAF 11.3 billion (US$20 million). These costs, however, should gradually diminish, and the project should begin turning a profit around the year 2000. Over the entire period, from 1997 to 2010, the project's net cumulative profits are estimated at over CFAF 96 billion, or US$172 million. 19. There will also be economic and social benefits in the form of job opportunities, estimated at CFAF 21 billion, or US$38 million, productivity gains, which are expected 5
 to amount to CFAF 32.3 billion, or US$57 million, and economies on the cost of capital investment, of the order of CFAF 10.8 billion, or US$19 million. 20. Finally, the project will also make it possible to realize unmeasurable indirect economic benefits in terms of productivity gains and an improvement in the allocation of public moneys. These benefits will come from the following factors: (a) increased competition in the industrial and service sectors; (b) an improvement in the regulatory structure and the elimination of price controls; (c) a reduction in poverty; and (d) a wider distribution of the shares in corporate equity. 21. Risks associated with the project. There are domestic and foreign political risks, and institutional risks linked to the program. The political risk stems from pressures exerted on the Government by people who have not been properly informed of the benefits to be derived from the program of reforms. The upcoming electoral period also presents a risk of slowing down the pace of reforms. As for institutional risks, they primarily have to do with the limits on the local institutional capacity to implement and manage reforms in an effective way. 22. Institutional aspects. During the past fifteen years, the Government's efforts to pull out of the parastatal sector have gone through seven different institutional changes. This is evidence that the implementing agencies are somewhat vulnerable to institutional and organizational crises. The tangible effect has been confusion as to roles or a failure to clearly define the powers and responsibilities of the various implementing agencies, the relevant technical ministries, and the management of the enterprises. This state of affairs has been aggravated by the absence of a regulatory and legal structure to govern the Government's divestiture policy. This was the situation in February 1996 when the Government promulgated a law on privatization and the organizational and functional restructuring of the executive agency in charge of the privatization program. 23. The new institutional structure for implementing the privatization program consists of two agencies: the Privatization Commission, the decision-making and monitoring agency, headed by the Minister of Finance and Economy, with the ministers of the relevant technical ministries related to the enterprises as members; and, the Privatization Committee, the secretariat and implementing body for the Commission. At the head of the Privatization Committee is a secretary, who is in charge of managing the program and providing technical guidance for the privatization operations, while maintaining a strategic view of the whole process. The Privatization Committee executes the decisions made by the Commission on privatization strategy and procedures and plays the role of permanent intermediary between the various actors and agents involved in the privatization process. It is also in charge of preparing, monitoring, implementing, and evaluating the operations carried out under the privatization program. 6
 SECTION B. DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION I. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 24. The Government's strategic objective, to which the project is expected to contribute, is growth of private investment and an increased participation of the non-oil private sector in the country's economic development. This project is designed to achieve this object in the following ways: (a) by creating an environment favorable to private investment; (b) by modernizing the legal and regulatory environment of the business sector; and (c) by competent and adequate project management. To this end, the project will comprise the following components: II. PROJECT COMPONENTS A. Communications 25. For years, the lack of a communications plan and strategy has stood in the way of popular support for the economic reforms. For instance, the reform of government enterprises has become synonymous with an imminent increase in unemployment, a further decline in living conditions, the sell-out of the nation's assets, and re-colonization. 26. The purpose of the communications component is to gain the people's support and political backing for privatization. To accomplish this, it will develop a local institutional capacity, which will design and implement an information program aimed at improving people's understanding of the issues involved in the economic reforms and at initiating a dialogue to promote greater participation by the people in implementing the economic program. This information program will at the same time allow the Government to gain a better understanding of the need for greater public support for its program of economic reforms and for using communications technology to this end. The project will provide the means to do the following: (a) Set up a privatization information center and communications unit, as part of the Privatization Committee; (b) Design and implement a training program to strengthen the Government's capacity to make effective use of the media and to establish communication and information links with labor unions, consumers, and political institutions; (c) Conduct opinion polls and other targeted research to assess public opinion on the projected reforms. The results of these studies will make it easier to define a communications strategy and to monitor the social and political environment of the reforms; 7
 (d) Instruct journalists as to the objectives of the economic reforms; and (e) Make sure that information on privatization and the economic reforms is distributed widely. 27. A memorandum describing the program and the responsibilities of the communications unit and its director was drawn up. This document, together with the detailed plan of action and the performance indicators (Annex II), was finalized during the appraisal mission. B. Regulatory Capacity Building 28. In order to transfer the operations of public enterprises to the private sector, the regulatory system must be revised. It is particularly essential to develop the capacity of government officials to regulate operators, and especially in sectors such as telecommunications, water and electricity, and transportation, where competition will be introduced and where there will be dominant operators. In view of this, the purpose of the regulatory capacity building component will be to establish the regulations governing competition and to put in place the required regulatory capacity. 29. To fulfill this mission, the project will provide the necessary support for the following: (a) Setting up a financially and legally independent, multisectoral regulatory structure for the water, electricity, telecommunications, postal, and transportation sectors; (b) Revising the sectoral codes and their implementing regulations to liberalize economic activities; and (c) Providing outside experts in regulation during the stage devoted to local capacity-building. 30. A technical report analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of the types of regulatory structure, such as sectoral vs. multisectoral, or ministerial vs. autonomous, was prepared. It enabled the Government to decide on an autonomous, multisectoral regulatory agency. The plan of action and the critical stages of this component have been finalized (Annex III). C. Public Enterprise Reform and Privatization 31. This component is designed to help in restructuring/reorganizing and privatizing the major government enterprises targeted. In fact, a law establishing the privatization rules for public sector enterprises was promulgated in February 1996 (Law 0 1/96 dated 8
 February 13, 1996), and a privatization program was attached to the supplementary budget of June 1996. Eight major economic sectors have been targeted for reorganization and privatization. They include the following sectors: agrofood, timber, industry and trade, posts and telecommunications, water and power, transportation, real property services, financial institutions, and computer services. Some of the enterprises were identified as priorities on the basis of criteria such as unrealized potential, or an urgent need to cut losses, and the like. Consequently, under this component: (a) five major sectors2 will be liberalized and the Government enterprises will be restructured and privatized; (b) evaluations and studies will be performed to prepare for implementation of the second phase of the program; and (c) the Privatization Committee, which is in charge of implementing the project, will be set up so that it can operate effectively. Office of Posts and Telecommunications (OPT) 32. In the summer of 1996, the Government adopted a sectoral policy statement that sets the main guidelines for reform of the postal and telecommunications sector. Among other things, this strategic document identifies the need to make the following changes, to be supported by the project: (a) Total separation of the postal service and telecommunications; (b) Reorganization of the telecommunications sector to create one primary telecommunications operator, grouping together TIG, OPT, and part of GABTEL's operations; (c) Immediate liberalization of all services offered by the sector, other than the basic service; (d) Immediate authorization of an expanded mobile telephone license; (e) Introduction of private capital by privatizing the principal operator; (f) Separation between operations and regulatory functions and introduction of the new regulatory functions needed for the sector to operate on the free market; and (g) Asystematic reorganization of the postal sector. 33. Restructuring Strategy. Separation between the postal service and telecommunications requires the two sectors to be reshaped and a specific strategy for restructuring each of them to be drawn up. The existing institutions in the telecommunications and postal sectors, including the TIG, OPT, GABTEL, and EMS 2 Telecommunications, water and electricity, comestible oils, rubber, and cement. 9
 Delta Plus, will have to be reorganized and the status of the new companies to be created will have to be defined. Thus, the separation and the restructuring plans will entail the following: For the OPT: (a) Establishing a strategy for each branch of activity beforehand; (b) Establishing an opening balance for each entity; (c) Designing new organization charts; and (d) Arranging for interim management of the residual OPT and the new enterprises, until the telecommunications operator is privatized and the heads of the postal company are appointed. For the telecommunications sector: (a) Adopting a new telecommunications code; (b) Establishing a new set of regulations, including licenses, specifications, and the like; (c) Establishing a new rate system and a specific timetable for adjusting the rates; (d) Establishing a new system of link-ups among operators; evaluating and revising allocation of the spectrum of frequencies; and (e) Privatizing the principal operator. For the postal sector: (a) Creating a commercial-type public corporation, by grouping the operations of the postal branch together with those of its subsidiary, EMS Delta Plus, and with financial services, subject to BEAC regulations; (b) Preparing and implementing a cost reduction program and a social plan, and (c) Implementing an active commercial development strategy and plan throughout the various branches of activity. 10

National Water and Electricity Company (SEEG) 36. The Government adopted a strategy to restructure the water and electricity sector that would enable it to attract private investment, reduce the cost of supplying services, increase the service area throughout the country, and limit the role of government to defining the sectoral policy and regulation. To implement this strategy, the following steps will be supervised and/or carried out with the support of this component: (a) Letting of concession contracts for water and electricity services;3 (b) Preparation of the laws and the implementing texts for the new regulatory system; and (c) Undertake a prospective study and determine a strategy for developing production and bringing electricity to rural areas. D. Participation by Nationals in Privatization 40. The Government is contemplating two procedures, which are not mutually exclusive, for selling off the Government's minority shareholdings to the public: (a) Direct sale of securities to Gabonese investors. This option will apply specifically to larger enterprises whose stocks can be sold--SEEG, and the future telecommunications and agribusiness companies. To conduct the sale of stocks on the market, a private commercial bank or a firm will be selected by competitive bidding; and (b) The creation of private mutual investment trusts. This option consists in transferring government shareholdings to various trusts. The stocks issued by these trusts, managed by private financial institutions (commercial banks), would be sold on the market. Shareholdings which are not considered to have a high enough value and do not have a profit potential would not be transferred to these funds. 41. A system of intermediation would be put in place according to the market structure set up with the support of the IFC, as part of efforts to organize a secondary market for SEEG stock. This system could make it possible to purchase and sell stocks under satisfactory conditions of transparency and security. 42. To facilitate these arrangements, the project will finance the following: 12
 (a) Preparation of laws and regulations authorizing the sale of the Government's minority shareholdings, establishment of private mutual investment trusts, a public offering, transactions on the secondary market, and establishment of a dealer function, in cooperation with the BEAC, to meet regional integration concerns; (b) Evaluation/valuation of shares held by the Government and determination of procedures for selling them; (c) Selection by competitive bid of a local financial institution responsible for managing the mutual investment trust and investing the stocks in that trust; (d) Selection of one or several commercial bank(s) to handle the direct sale of shares; and (e) Technical support for dealers in determining the compensation arrangements with regard to the stocks. The terms of reference and the plan of action with performance indicators have been finalized and agreed with the Government. E. Modernizing the Legal Environment for Business 43. This component will provide assistance in putting in place an institutional and a legal environment conducive to development of the private sector, based on the guidelines contained in the Investment Charter being prepared by the Government. The project will finance the following activities in this area: Business Law 44. Gabon has initiated proceedings to ratify the treaty creating the Organization for Harmonization of Business Law in Africa (OHADA). The project will support efforts to incorporate the uniform acts in Gabonese legislation. It will provide the following services to this end: (a) Legal technical assistance to legislative agencies, with a view to the future entry into force of the uniform acts of OHADA, including (i) compiling a list and computerizing all the applicable laws in Gabon, and (ii) analyzing the laws affected by the OHADA project to identify existing laws that will have to be abrogated, amended, or updated, and to identify and draft supplementary laws that will prove necessary; 13
 (b) Support for efforts to disseminate the new business laws and the new Investment Charter by printing, publishing, and distributing the texts, and organization of both general and specific seminars for the various economic operators and legal practitioners; and (c) Assistance in defining and implementing procedures for settling disputes in business law by (i) a study concerning the type of structures to put in place (for instance, establishing chambers specializing in business law in the existing courts, or creating specialized courts, or introducing a national commercial arbitration procedure, and (ii) support for setting up structures to be used at the end of the study, including specialized training required by judges and court employees, and seminars for other legal practitioners and persons working in the business world.  SECTION C. PROJECT COSTS AND ADMINISTRATION I. PROJECT COSTS 48. The total cost of the project, including contingencies, is estimated at FF 90 millions, net of taxes. The Government's contribution to the project will be FF 34 million, or 37% of the total project cost.  SECTION D. PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION I. PROJECT MANAGEMENT 61. The Minister of Finance, Economy, Budget, and Shareholdings is the official responsible for implementing the project. To fulfill its mission effectively, the Privatization Committee will hire a team of qualified nationals consisting of professionals in charge of operations--financial analysts, economists, sectoral engineers or technicians and attorneys--and an accounts manager, an administrative assistant, and a support person. The Privatization Committee will also rely on the enterprises and sectoral ministries, and on one consulting firm for advice on privatization and on another specializing in communications. The two resident experts provided by these firms will work in close cooperation. Their primary function will be to train and develop the capacity of the staff of the Privatization Committee. The institutional plan for implementing this project, discussed and agreed with the Government, is presented in Annex IX. II. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN 62. A project implementation plan was drawn up with the assistance of a project computer specialist (Annex VII). This plan will be used by the Project Coordinator and by the heads of the various components as a tool for monitoring the project, and by the Government and donors for monitoring the reforms. The plan observes all the IBRD procedures, and time and resource constraints, and it makes it possible to draw up periodic progress reports. It also reflects the action already taken by the Government. The project will be implemented over a 48-month period, starting on the date it takes effect, scheduled for June 30, 1997. The project will be completed by June 30, 2001. III. REPORTING AND MONITORING 63. Every six months, starting on the date the loan takes effect, the Project Coordinator will send the IBRD a detailed project implementation report. It will indicate the corrective actions or measures envisaged by the Government. The borrower will submit a project completion report to the IBRD no later than six months following the closing date of the loan. IV. SUPERVISION 65. For the Government (a) Sectoral units consisting of representatives designated by technical ministries, members of the Privatization Committee, and a task manager for each area will ensure regular monitoring of each component and will provide periodic progress reports; and (b) The project coordinator and the component leaders will use the Project management software to ensure planned management of project activities and results. 66. doc.repnme: Gabon - Privatization and Regulatory Capacity Building Technical Assistance Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Privatization and Regulatory Capacity Building Technical Assistance Project is to increase the level of private sector investment in Gabon. The current program calls for: (a) facilitating rapid divestiture from state enterprises with major spin-off effects on factor costs and employment, in transport, power, telecommunications, and the largest agro-businesses; and (b) improving the efficiency of state spending in core areas directly aimed at poverty reduction. The project has five components: (1) Public understanding and support of the reform program -obtained by: (a) setting up and operating an information unit; (b) building government capacity to use the media effectively and establishing contacts with influential constituencies; (c) researching public opinion; and (d) training journalists on reporting economic and governance issues. (2) Regulatory framework and capacity building -financing (a) a regulatory agency for the infrastructure subsectors; (b) implementing regulations and laws to attract private investment; and (c) the training of regulatory agency staff. (3) Privatizing selected large public enterprises in priority sectors with financing for consultant and advisory services. (4) Increasing local participation in privatization -preparing to sell the government's minority shares by: (a) drafting regulations on financial markets, trading activities, and financial intermediaries; and (b) passing laws to establish and regulate mutual funds; and (c) updating current laws on securities issuance. (5) Improving the business environment and promoting investment -by financing (a) computerizing legal texts; (b) repealing, amending, updating, or enacting applicable business laws; (c) reviewing existing and alternative business dispute resolution mechanisms; (d) revising the Labor Code; and (e) auditing and financially restructuring the national social security agency.
